awd_titl_txt: CISE-MSI: RCBP-ED: CNS: Data Science and Engineering for Agriculture Automation
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

Data science is an interdisciplinary field in which statistical, computer science, and mathematical concepts overlap for the acquisition, analysis, and extraction of valuable insights from large datasets.  Similarly, data engineering promotes the flow and accession of data through the developing and application of software tools, interfaces and mechanisms. Together, tools from these fields are often applied to other domains (e.g., medicine, agriculture, urban planning) to generate new understanding from data.  But insights gained through data science and engineering tools are far superior when applied in a transdisciplinary and collaborative approach that includes expertise in both the data tools and the fields to which they are being applied. To develop better insights into improving the state of nutrition-associated disorders in urban “food deserts,” the Department of Computer Science and Information Technology at the University of the District of Columbia will expand its capacity to train Accelerated Bachelor’s/Master’s students using an integrated training model in data science and engineering (IMDSE). This new program will build research capacity through transdisciplinary education program that systematically integrates data science, data engineering, and agriculture automation.

The IMDSE program will catalyze scientific discovery and innovation by training students in data science and engineering and urban aquaponics automation. Aquaponics automation focuses on creating sustainable food production in urban areas and requires knowledge and application of deep machine learning, cloud computing, data science and engineering technologies, internet-of-things technologies, sensor and actuator technologies, wireless communications, and web programming, as well as agriculture, agronomy, nutrition, biology, public health, and environmental sciences. This IMDSE program will be a first and original foundation for training undergraduate and graduate students with both experiential and transdisciplinary expertise in targeted interdisciplinary and convergent research areas. While the initial target is on agriculture automation, other research areas requiring insights from big data science and engineering will be included as the program grows into a national-scale program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.inst_name: University of the District of Columbia

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of the District of Columbia

por.por_cntn:
This project developed an innovative, research-integrated training program known as the Integrated Model for Data Science and Engineering (IMDSE). The IMDSE program introduced a transdisciplinary curriculum and research that integrates Data Science and Engineering (DSE) for urban agriculture automation, thereby enhancing the Accelerated Bachelors/Masters program in the Department of Computer Science and Information Technology at the University of the District of Columbia. The outcomes of this project include significant contributions to intellectual advancement and societal impact, which are detailed in the paragraphs below.

The IMDSE empowers students to leverage advanced computational technologies, such as deep learning, cloud computing, Internet of Things, and data engineering, to address pressing challenges in sustainable agriculture.  In addition to technical competencies, students gain exposure to critical domains such as agriculture, nutrition, biology, environmental science, and public health, fostering a comprehensive understanding of the intersection between these disciplines to promote sustainable and healthy communities.

The IMDSE program equips students to conduct transdisciplinary research, addressing multifaceted challenges requiring data-driven solutions across various fields. This is facilitated through peer teaching, project-based learning, and experiential learning, as depicted in Figure 1. By involving students from non-computer science backgrounds in DSE courses, the IMDSE program takes an inclusive approach to technological education. In addition, the use of prompt-based development environments, supported by Large Language Models, democratizes access to complex programming tasks, enabling students from diverse academic backgrounds to contribute to AI-driven technologies. For example, students who may not have formal training in programming can use prompt-based tools to generate code snippets, debug errors, and iterate on solutions with guidance, thus overcoming common challenges such as syntax complexity and logic structuring. This practical support empowers them to actively participate in projects and innovations that would otherwise be inaccessible. This approach not only lowers barriers to programming but also significantly broadens participation in AI research and innovation across disciplines.

Beyond technical education, the IMDSE program delivers broader impacts that extend well beyond the classroom setting. It emphasizes transdisciplinary expertise, preparing students to engage in research areas that integrate data science, engineering, and agricultural automation, resulting in six peer-reviewed publications covering topics such as DSE and machine learning models in aquaponics. With additional research opportunities anticipated at UDC, the IMDSE program is well-positioned to grow into a national initiative, providing students across the country with exposure to a broad spectrum of interdisciplinary research and educational experiences.

The IMDSE program aims to cultivate the next generation of DSE researchers, equipping them to address critical issues in data-driven analysis and decision-making. Graduates of the program are prepared for diverse career paths across academia, industry, government, and non-profit sectors, with a focus on data-intensive research requiring cross-disciplinary expertise.

The program also contributes significantly to public engagement and outreach. Cross-registration opportunities in DSE courses encourage broader student participation in these fields, while public workshops and outreach activities raise awareness of the critical role data science and engineering play in addressing societal challenges. These initiatives are expected to catalyze scientific discovery and drive innovation in emerging fields, yielding long-term societal benefits.

Overall, the IMDSE program represents a pioneering effort that integrates data science, engineering, and agriculture in a unique and impactful manner. By training students to apply DSE methodologies in contexts such as urban aquaponics, the program is reshaping educational paradigms and advancing research methodologies in ways that promise enduring impacts. As the program continues to expand, it will provide more students with opportunities to engage in cutting-edge research, thereby preparing them for influential careers in science, technology, and beyond.


Last Modified: 10/25/2024
Modified by: Junwhan Kim
